title: 106_s1346
content: The Act may be cited as the "Independent Office of Advocacy Act". Congress acknowledges the burden of excessive regulations on small businesses and the reluctance of Federal agencies to comply with statutory requirements, highlighting the role of the Office of Advocacy in advocating for small businesses. The Office of Advocacy ensures agencies comply with statutory obligations and advocates for small businesses independently from the Small Business Administration or other executive branch agencies, requiring sufficient resources for effective impact assessment. The Office of Advocacy requires adequate resources to conduct research on the impact of regulations on small businesses and provides valuable advice to Congress and executive branch agencies. The Office of Advocacy requires resources for researching regulations' impact on small businesses and advising Congress and executive agencies. The Office of Advocacy aims to have independence and sufficient funding to advocate for small businesses. It must report to key committees and the Small Business Administration to keep them informed on issues affecting small businesses and the need for corrective action. Separate appropriations authorization is also provided. The Office of Advocacy seeks independence and adequate funding to advocate for small businesses. It must report to key committees and the Small Business Administration on issues affecting small businesses, the need for corrective action, and agency compliance with relevant laws. Authorization for separate appropriations is also included to enhance the Office's role. The Small Business Act is amended to include a new section, SEC. 32, establishing the Office of Advocacy. The Small Business Act is amended to establish the Office of Advocacy, with the Chief Counsel appointed by the President from civilian life. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy shall be appointed by the President from civilian life, with advice and consent of the Senate, based on fitness for the role. The appointee cannot have been an officer or employee of the Small Business Administration in the 5 years prior to appointment. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy, appointed by the President, must not have served in the Small Business Administration for 5 years prior. The President can remove the Chief Counsel, with notification to Congress. Each appropriation request by the Administration must include a separate request for the Office's funding. The Office's primary functions are specified. The Office, as specified in title 31, United States Code, focuses on examining the role of small businesses in the economy and their contributions to various aspects such as competition, innovation, and employment opportunities. The Office focuses on examining the role of small businesses in the economy, including their contributions to competition, innovation, and employment opportunities. It also assesses Federal subsidy programs for small businesses and proposes reducing emphasis on these programs in favor of general assistance programs. Additionally, it measures the direct costs and effects of government regulation on small businesses and suggests proposals to eliminate excessive or unnecessary regulations. The Office examines the impact of government regulation on small businesses and proposes eliminating excessive or unnecessary regulations. It also studies the tax structure's effect on small businesses and suggests changes to enhance their contribution to the economy. Additionally, it assesses the ability of financial markets to meet small business credit needs and evaluates the impact of government demands on credit for small businesses. The Office aims to study financial markets' ability to meet small business credit needs and assess the impact of government demands on credit. It also focuses on recommending methods for delivering financial assistance to minority and women-owned enterprises, generating markets for goods and services, and providing effective business education and training. The Office evaluates efforts to assist minority and women-owned enterprises, makes recommendations for small business development, and suggests measures to create an inclusive business environment. The Office evaluates efforts to assist minority and women-owned enterprises, makes recommendations for small business development, and suggests measures to create an inclusive business environment. It recommends specific measures for creating an environment where all businesses can compete effectively and expand, determines criteria for defining small businesses, and submits reports to relevant committees. The Office evaluates efforts to assist minority and women-owned enterprises, makes recommendations for small business development, suggests measures for creating an inclusive business environment, and serves as a focal point for receiving complaints and suggestions regarding policies. It also recommends specific measures for creating a competitive business environment and submits reports to relevant committees. The Office serves as a focal point for receiving complaints, criticisms, and suggestions regarding policies affecting small businesses. It also counsels small businesses on resolving issues with the Federal Government and develops proposals for improving agency policies. The Office of Small Business Advocacy proposes activities to fulfill its purposes, represents small businesses before other agencies, and collaborates with public and private entities to disseminate information about government programs for small businesses. The Chief Counsel of the Office of Small Business Advocacy has the authority to appoint additional personnel as needed to fulfill the office's duties, without being bound by civil service laws and regulations. The Chief Counsel of the Office of Small Business Advocacy can appoint and terminate personnel as necessary, with the authority to set their compensation without following certain federal regulations, up to a maximum rate of GS-15. The Chief Counsel of the Office of Small Business Advocacy has the authority to appoint and terminate personnel, setting their compensation up to the maximum rate of GS-15. Additionally, the Chief Counsel can procure temporary services and consult with others in carrying out this section. The Chief Counsel of the Office of Small Business Advocacy can consult with experts in small business investment, venture capital, banking, and regulatory fields, as well as individuals with expertise in law, economics, and finance. The Chief Counsel of the Office of Small Business Advocacy can consult with experts in small business investment, venture capital, banking, law, economics, and finance. They may also use the services of the National Advisory Council and appoint advisory boards or committees as needed, hold hearings, and act as necessary. The Administrator shall provide the Office with necessary office space, equipment, supplies, and communication facilities for its operation at central and field office locations. Maintenance services for the offices and equipment will also be provided. The Chief Counsel shall secure information from Federal agencies as needed and submit annual reports to the President and Committees. The Chief Counsel submits annual reports on agency compliance with chapter 6 of title 5, United States Code to the President and relevant committees. The Chief Counsel may prepare additional reports as deemed appropriate, which shall not be submitted to any other government entity before being sent to the President and Congress. Authorization of appropriations is also provided. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Office to carry out the section, with available funds without fiscal year limitation. Title II of Public Law 94-305 is repealed, and the incumbent Chief Counsel for Advocacy at the Small Business Administration will continue to serve. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration will continue to serve in that position after the enactment of this Act. The Senate passed the Act on November 5, 1999, with Gary Sisco as the Secretary.
